introduction.p: As an illustration of collision, consider hanging two pendula next to each other as shown in . After you let go of the pendulum, say an instant before (a) in the figure, ball 1 accelerates under the influence of external forces of weight (m_1 g) and tension (T_1).

shows relations of momentum vectors before collision and after collision. The total moementum vector before the collision is the same vector as after the collision. Therefore, if total momentum vector before the collision falls in xy-plane, it will be also in the xy-plane after the collision. You can illustrate that if three of the four momentum vectors shown in the figure falls in xy-plane, the fourth one must also be in xy-plane.

statement.p: Two carts of masses 200\text{ g} and 300\text{ g} are moving towards each other on a straight track with speeds of 10\text{ m/s} and 15\text{ m/s} respectively. Immediately after the collision, the 200\text{-g} cart reverses direction and moves with a speed of 8\text{ m/s}.
What is the velocity (i.e. speed and direction) of the 300\text{-g} cart after collision?

answer.p: 3.0\text{ m/s}, opposite to the initial direction of 200\text{-g} cart.

solution.p: Since all momenta lie along the same line, we choose x axis to be that line. We can arbitrarily choose the direction of motion of the 200\text{-g} cart to be the direction of the positive x axis.

We denote the x component of the unknown velocity by v_{2x}^\prime. The conservation of momentum along the x axis gives the following equation, where the left side is the before and the right side the after.
0.2 \text{ kg} \times 10 \text{ m/s} + 0.3 \text{ kg} \times (- 15 \text{ m/s} ) = 0.2 \text{ kg} \times ( - 8 \text{ m/s} ) + 0.3 \text{ kg}\times v_{2x}^\prime.
Therefore, v_{2x}^\prime = - 3.0\text{ m/s}. That is, after the collision, the 300\text{-g} cart continues to move in the negative x direction, the same direction it had before the collision, but now with speed 3.0\text{ m/s}.

statement.p: Two balls A and B of masses 0.4\text{ kg} and 0.45\text{ kg} are moving towards each other and collide as shown in .

Before the collision, A has speed 5\text{ m/s} and B has speed 8\text{ m/s}. The collision happens, not head-on, but at an angle so that, after the collision, ball A continues in the direction that is 15^{\circ} to its original direction at a speed of 10\text{ m/s}. What is the velocity of ball B after the collision?

answer.p: 12.3\text{ m/s}, 10.8^{\circ} counterclockwise from the negative x axis

solution.p:
We need to find the magnitude and direction of the velocity \vec v_{B,f}. For brevity, let us denote the components of this velocity by (v_x,\, v_y) . Setting up the conservation of momentum across the event of collision in the x and y directions we get the following two equations.
\amp 0.4\times 5 + 0.45\times (-8) = 0.4\times 10\,\cos\,15^{\circ} + 0.45\, v_x \amp 0 + 0 = 0.4\times 10\,\sin\,15^{\circ} + 0.45\, v_y
Solving them for v_x and v_y we find
v_x = -12.1\text{ m/s},\ \ v_y = -2.3\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, the magnitude and angle with the x axis is
\amp v = \sqrt{ 12.1^2 + 2.3^2 } = 12.3\text{ m/s}, \amp \theta = 10.8^{\circ}.
We now interpret the direction from this angle and the quadrant of (v_x, v_y). Since (-12.1,\, -2.3) is in the third quadrant, the direction is 10.8^{\circ} counterclockwise from the negative x axis.

subsection.title: Elastic Collision
subsection.p:
A collision is said to be elastic if, in addition to the conservation of momentum, kinetic energy is also conserved. Kinetic energy of a particle of mass m and speed v is defined by
KE = \dfrac{1}{2} m v^2.
This can also be written as p^2/2m by using magnitude of momentum as p=mv. We say that a collision is a a head-on collision if momenta before and after collision are along one line as illustrated in .

figure.caption: A head-on collision between two balls resulting in motion along x axis. The collision would be elastic, if in addition to the momentum conservation, kinetic energy is also conserved.

subsection.p:
In a head-on collision momentum conservation will produce one equation along the axis of the momenta. If the collision is elastic, we will also have an equation for the conservation of kinetic energy. Refering to the quantities shown in we will have
\amp m_1 v_{1x} + m_2 v_{2x} = m_1 {v'}_{1x} + m_2 {v'}_{2x}, \amp \dfrac{1}{2}m_1 v_{1x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2 v_{2x}^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}m_1 {v'}_{1x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2 {v'}_{2x}^2.
If collision occurs in xy-plane, then we would get three equations.
\amp m_1 v_{1x} + m_2 v_{2x} = m_1 {v'}_{1x} + m_2 {v'}_{2x}, \amp m_1 v_{1y} + m_2 v_{2y} = m_1 {v'}_{1y} + m_2 {v'}_{2y}, \amp \dfrac{1}{2}m_1 v_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2 v_2^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}m_1 {v'}_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2 {v'}_2^2,
where
v_1^2 = v_{1x}^2 + v_{1y}^2,
and similarly for v_2^2, {v'}_1^2 and {v'}_2^2.

If kinetic energy is not conserved, we say that the collision is inelastic. In a perfectly inelastic collision, the two bodies get stuck together and move as one. We will have examples of elastic collisions in the chapter on energy.

example.title: One Dimensional Elastic Collision of Two blocks of Different Masses

statement.p: A block of mass m moving with speed v_0=5\text{ m/s} collides head on with another block of mass 3m at rest. After an elastic collision, m moves in the opposite direction to its original direction. Find speeds of the two blocks after the elastic collision.

solution.p:
Let u and v be the speeds after collision for blocks m and 3m respectively. Since motion is along one axis, we take that axis to be x-axis with original direction to be positive x-axis. Since the collision is elastic, we will get both momentum and kinetic energy conservations.
\amp x\text{-momentum: } m v_0 = m u + 3 m v. \amp \text{kinetic energy: } \frac{1}{2}m v_0^2 = \frac{1}{2}m u^2 + \frac{1}{2}3m v^2.
These can be simplified to
\amp u + 3 v = 5. \amp u^2 + 3 v^2 = 25.
Eliminating v, we get
u^2 - \frac{5}{2}\,u -\frac{25}{2} = 0.
This gives u=5, -5/2. If u=5, v=0, which is not the solution we seek. Using u=-5/2, we get
v = \frac{1}{3}( 5-u ) = \frac{5}{2}.

example.title: Resulting Motion After a Head-on Collision - Elastic Versus Inelastic

statement.p: Two balls A and B of masses m_A = 0.2\text{ kg} and m_B = 0.4\text{ kg} collide head on. Before the collision, both balls are moving in the same direction with speeds v_A = 10\text{ m/s} and v_B = 8\text{ m/s}. Find their velocities after the collision if (a) the collision is elastic and (b) if the two balls stick together and move as one.

answer.p: (a) (v_A = 22/3\text{ m/s},\ v_B = 28/3\text{ m/s}), (b) v_A = v_B = 26/3\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Suppose the motion is along x axis. For brevity in equations, let u and v denote the x components of the velocities of A and B, respectively. Since in this part we are assuming that the collision is elastic, we will have two conditions to satisfy.
\amp 0.2\times 10 + 0.4\times 8 = 0.2\,u + 0.4\, v, \amp \dfrac{1}{2}\ 0.2\times 10^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\ 0.4\times 8^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}\ 0.2\,u^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\ 0.4\, v^2.
Simplifying these equations, we get
\amp u + 2 v = 26, \amp u^2 + 2 v^2 = 228.
Solving them we get (u = 10,\ v=8) and (u = 22/3,\ v=28/3). The first of these states that there is no collision, so we drop it. The seond answer is what will happen due to the elastic collision.
\text{After elastic collision: } v_A = \dfrac{22}{3}\text{ m/s},\ \ v_B = \dfrac{28}{3}\text{ m/s}.
Since the values are positive, both A and B still moving towards the positive xaxis.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Since the two balls stick together, they will have same velocity after the collision. Let their common x-velocity be denoted by v. Setting up conservation of momentum gives
0.2\times 10 + 0.4\times 8 = (0.2 + 0.4)\, v.
Solving this for v we get
v = \dfrac{26}{3}\text{ m/s}.

example.title: Colliding Bodies Stuck Together - Inelastic Collision

statement.p: Two balls A and B of mass 0.4\text{ kg} and 0.45\text{ kg} are moving towards each other with speeds 5\text{ m/s} and 8\text{ m/s} respectively.
After collision, they stick together, and then move as one rigid object.
Find the speed and direction in which the pair moves.

answer.p: 1.9\text{ m/s} towards the negative x axis.

solution.p: In the figure, the final velocity direction is taken to be arbitrary to the right. We will actually find the x component of the final velocity, v_{f,x} , whose sign will be indiactive of the direction.

The conservation of momentum along the x axis will give rise to the following equation.
0.4\times 5 + 0.45\times (-8) = (0.4 + 0.45)\, v_{f,x},
which gives
v_{f,x} = -1.9\text{ m/s}.
Since v_{f,x} \lt 0, the pair move towards the negative x axis.

subsection.title: Impulse of Internal Forces
subsection.p: In a collision, although the total momentum of the colliding bodies do not change, the individual momenta do change. This is due to the impulse they exert on each other. From the change in the momentum of one body, we get the impulse by the other body. By looking at the change in momentum of the body and an estimate of the duration \Delta t of their contact, we can ascertain the average force between the bodies during the collision.

\amp \vec p_{1,f} - \vec p_{1,i} = \vec F_{\text{on 1}}^{\text{by 2}}\, \Delta t, \amp \vec p_{2,f} - \vec p_{2,i} = \vec F_{\text{on 2}}^{\text{by 1}}\, \Delta t,
where
\vec F_{\text{on 1}}^{\text{by 2}} = - \vec F_{\text{on 2}}^{\text{by 1}}.
If we know the momentum change of one colliding body and have a good estimate of the duration \Delta t for which the two objects were in contact, these equations can be used to obtain an estimate of the average force \vec F_{\text{ave}} = \vec F_{\text{on 1}}^{\text{by 2}} between the two bodies.

subsection.title: Summary of Formulas for Collision
subsection.p:
We get two types of information in collision - a redistribution of total momentum among the colliding bodies and impulse on each body.
\amp \vec p_{1,i} + \vec p_{2,i} = \vec p_{1,f} + \vec p_{2,f}, \amp \vec p_{1,f} - \vec p_{1,i} = \vec J_\text{on 1}.
From the impulse and an estimate of the collision duration we can obtain an estimate of the averge force during the collision, whose magnitude will be
F_\text{av} = \dfrac{J_\text{on 1}}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{|\Delta p_1|}{\Delta t}.
Additionally, if collision is elastic,
\frac{p_{1,i}^2}{2m_1} + \frac{p_{2,i}^2}{2m_2} = \frac{p_{1,f}^2}{2m_1} + \frac{p_{2,f}^2}{2m_2},
where I have written Kinetic energy as
KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{p^2}{2m}.

exercise.title: Bullet Passing Through a Block of Wood

statement.p: A 15-gram bullet is fired at a 5.0-kg block of wood sitting on a frictionless table. The bullet enters the wood at 400\text{ m/s}, passes through the wood, and exits at 100\text{ m/s} . What is the speed of the wood block immediately after the bullet exits, ignoring any mass loss of the wood in the process.

solution.p:
Let index 1 refer to the bullet and 2 to the block. Let positive x axis be in the direction of the velocity of the bullet. From the conservation of momentum along the x axis, we immediately get the following equation.
m_1v_{1,x} + 0 = m_1 v_{1,x}^\prime + m_2 v_{2,x}^\prime.
We solve this for v_{2,x}^\prime . We also note that x components of all the velocity are positive.
v_{2,x}^\prime \amp = \dfrac{m_1}{m_2}\left(v_{1,x} - v_{1,x}^\prime \right), \amp = \dfrac{0.015}{5}\left(400 - 100 \right) = 0.9\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: A Projectile Breaking up in Mid Air

statement.p: A projectile of mass 2\text{ kg} moving at 50\text{ m/s} breaks up in mid air into two pieces as shown in . The larger piece comes out at 60\text{ m/s} in the forward direction, and the smaller piece at 100\text{ m/s} in the backward direction.
What are the masses of the two pieces?

hint.p: Use conservation of momentum using the forward-bacward direction as the x axis.

solution.p: The breaking up process is reverse of sticking together process. In both situations, we have only the internal forces. Therefore, momentum is conserved.

sidebyside.p: Since the momentum conservation is a vector equation, we can choose axes to simplify that equation. Here, if we choose positive x-axis to point in the forward direction, as shown in the figure below, we need to work with only x-components.

solution.p:
Implementing momentum conservation equation we get
2\times 50 = 60\,m_1 + (-100)\, m_2,
and mass conservation gives
m_1 + m_2 = 2.
Therefore, we replace m_2 by 2 - m_1 in Eq. to get
100 = 60\,m_1 - 100\times (2 - m_1),
which can be solved for m_1 .
m_1 = 300/160 = 1.875\text{ kg}.
From Eq.
m_2 = 2 - 1.875 = 0.125\text{ kg}.

exercise.title: Recoil of a Tennis Ball Machine

statement.p: A tennis ball machine is placed on a frictionless table. Let M be the mass of ball machine and m the mass of the tennis ball. Initially, the ball machine and ball are at rest.

sidebyside.p: The ball machine shoots ball at speed u with respect to the machine, when the machine itself is recoiling. The ball comes out at angle \theta above the horizontal as shown in . What will be the recoil speed V of the ball machine with respect to the table?

hint.p: Use conservation of momentum with respect to the table.

solution.p: We will use conservation of momentum with in the frame of the table. Therefore, we need to express all velocities with respect to the table.

Let x-axis point horizontally to the right. Then, after the shot, the ball machine has the x-velocity,
V_x = - V,
and the ball has the x-velocity
v_x = u\cos\theta - V.
Make sure you understand why V needs to be subtracted to get velocity of ball with respect to the table.

Then, x-component of the conservation of momentum equation gives
(M+m)\times 0 = m (u\cos\theta - V) + M (-V),
where -V has negative sign since we are using x-component. Solving for V we havbe
V = \frac{ m u\cos\theta. }{M+m}.

exercise.title: Motion of Two Pieces in a One Dimensional Explosion

statement.p: A rocket of mass M is flying at a speed 100\text{ m/s} with respect to ground. Suddenly it breaks up into two pieces of mass 0.3M (piece A) and 0.7M (piece B). After the explosion, B continues in the forward direction with a new speed V with respect to ground and A moves in the backward direction with speed u=150\text{m/s} relative to the B. Find the speed of B.

hint.p: Total momentum is conserved in an explosion.

solution.p: The explosion involves only internal forces between the two resulting pieces. Therefore, total momentum is conserved. But, we need to make sure we express all momenta with respect to the same reference, which we will take to be ground.

Let forward direction be positive x-axis direction as shown in . Then, x-component of velocities of original and A and B pieces with respect to ground will be
\amp v_x(\text{original}) = 100\text{ m/s}. \amp v_x(A) = v_x(\text{ of B with respect to ground}) + v_x(\text{ of a with respect to B}) = V - 150. \amp v_x(B) = V .

Conservation of momentum will yield
100\,M = 0.3\,M\,(V-150) + 0.7\,M\,V\ \ \longrightarrow\ \ V = 145\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Motion of Two Pieces in a Two Dimensional Explosion

statement.p: shows a rocket of mass M moving in space with speed v_0=110\text{ m/s} with respect to ground, and then exploding in two pieces. Let the masses of the two pieces A and B be 0.2M and 0.8M respectively. Piece A is seen to move with speed u in the direction \phi=60^\circ as seen by a ground-based observer. Larger piece B moves with speed V in the direction \theta=30^\circ by the ground-based observer. Find values of u and V.

hint.p: Apply conservation of momentum along x and y axis.

solution.p:
Using we can write conservation of momentum along x and y axis.
\amp 0.8 M V \cos\theta - 0.2 M u \cos\phi = M v_0. \amp 0.8 M V \sin\theta - 0.2 M u \sin\phi = 0.
From the second equation, we get
V = \frac{1}{4}\,u\,\frac{\sin\phi}{\sin\theta} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\,u.
Using this in Eq. gives
0.8\times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\,u\,\cos\theta - 0.2\,\,\cos\phi = v_0.
Solving this for u, we get
u = 5 v_0 = 550\text{ m/s}.
Therefore,
V = \frac{5\sqrt{3}}{4}v_0 = 238\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: One Dimensional Collision of Two blocks of Different Masses

statement.p: A block of mass m moving with speed 5\text{ m/s} collides head on with another block of mass am at rest, where a\gt 0. After collision, m moves in the opposite direction to its original direction with the same speed as before the collision. (a) Find speed of the the other block. (b) Prove that in the limit a\rightarrow \infty, the collision will be elastic.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
Let v be the speed of the second block after collision. Using x-axis along the direction of motion, we get
\amp x\text{-momentum: } m \times 5 = m \times (-5) + a m v.
This gives
v = \frac{10}{a}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
Let us find the difference in kinetic energy.
\Delta\,KE \amp = \left[ \frac{1}{2} (am) \left( \frac{10}{a}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{2}m \times 5^2 \right] - \frac{1}{2}m \times 5^2 \amp = \frac{50\,m}{a}.
This will be zero as a\rightarrow \infty. Therefore, kinetic energy will be also consered in this limit, which will mean that for the first block to bounce back with the same speed, the collision will be elastic if the second block has infinite mass.
